{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

DiscretePrior

DiscretePrior is now built into GTSAM:

{% raw %} 
from gtbook.display import show
C = 0, 5  # A key is an identifier and a cardinality
prior = gtsam.DiscreteDistribution(C, "25/20/30/20/5")
test_eq(prior.empty(), False)

# TODO: this does not support formatting yet
show(prior)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
prior_probability_for_3 = prior(3)
test_eq(prior_probability_for_3, 0.2)
{% endraw %}

Variables

We would like to make it easier for people to create discrete variables, with a meaningful name, and meaningful strings associated with discrete values. Below is it possible design:

{% raw %}

class Variables[source]

Variables()

A problem domain for discrete variables.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Here is an example:

{% raw %} 
variables = Variables()
categories = ["cardboard", "paper", "can", "scrap metal", "bottle"]
Category = variables.discrete("Category", categories)

test_eq(variables.name(Category), "Category")
test_eq(variables.domain(Category), categories)
{% endraw %}

Now it can provide a key formatter for us:

{% raw %} 
keyFormatter = variables.keyFormatter()
test_eq(keyFormatter(Category[0]), "Category")
{% endraw %}

We can also create a names dictionary for the choices made in teh decision tree:

{% raw %} 
names = variables.names()
test_eq(isinstance(names, dict), True)
test_eq(len(names), 1)
test_eq(names, {0: ['cardboard', 'paper', 'can', 'scrap metal', 'bottle']})
{% endraw %}

Binary variables are supported as a special case:

{% raw %} 
Conductivity = variables.binary("Conductivity")
test_eq(variables.domain(Conductivity), ["false", "true"])
{% endraw %}

Providing the domains to the Variables data structure also makes it easy to create

{% raw %} 
assignment = variables.assignment({Category: "can"})
test_eq(isinstance(assignment, gtsam.DiscreteValues), True)
test_eq(assignment[C[0]], categories.index("can"))
{% endraw %}

We also create a markdown renderer for DiscreteValues , awaiting the ability of pybind11 to wrap classes ingereited from STL containers:

{% raw %} 
test_eq(variables.values_markdown(assignment),
        '|Variable|value|\n|:-:|:-:|\n|Category|can|\n')
{% endraw %}

As of version 0.0.14 , we also support generating a set of discrete keys with integer indices, to support reasoning over time:

{% raw %} 
n = variables.size()

# add 5 variables
states = variables.discrete_series('s', range(5), ["no", "yes"])
test_eq(variables.size(), n+5)

# calling twice should not add any more
states = variables.discrete_series('s', range(5), ["no", "yes"])
test_eq(variables.size(), n+5)

test_eq(variables.name(states[0]), "s0")
test_eq(variables.domain(states[0]), ["no", "yes"])
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
n = variables.size()

# expand range
states = variables.discrete_series('s', range(10), ["no", "yes"])
test_eq(variables.size(), n+5)
test_eq(variables.name(states[9]), "s9")
{% endraw %}

It would be nice to inspect variables:

{% raw %} 
variables
VariableDomain
Categorycardboard, paper, can, scrap metal, bottle
Conductivityfalse, true
s0no, yes
s1no, yes
s2no, yes
s3no, yes
s4no, yes
s5no, yes
s6no, yes
s7no, yes
s8no, yes
s9no, yes
{% endraw %}
